{{Use British English|date=September 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{third-party|date=September 2018}} '''Cyber Centurion''' is a cyber security competition for school children from the age of 12,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cybersecuritychallenge.org.uk/app/uploads/2016/08/MCN-1352-Cyber-Centurion-A5-info-graphic-3-for-Schools-DS-FINAL.pdf|title=Cyber Centurion Infographic|last=|first=|date=|website=cybersecuritychallenge.org.uk|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> run in the United Kingdom by Cyber Security Challenge UK.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://cybersecuritychallenge.org.uk/competitions/cybercenturion|title=CyberCenturion - Cyber Security Challenge UK|work=Cyber Security Challenge UK|access-date=2017-04-23|language=en-US}}</ref> It mirrors [[CyberPatriot]], the US version run by the [[Air Force Association]].<ref name="CyberPatriot">{{cite web |title=CyberPatriot |url=https://www.northropgrumman.com/CorporateResponsibility/Pages/CyberPatriot.aspx |website=Northrop Grumman |publisher=Northrup Grumman |accessdate=15 September 2018}}</ref> Cyber Centurion is sponsored by [[Northrop Grumman]]<ref name="tnmoc.org">{{Cite web|url=http://www.tnmoc.org/news/news-releases/national-cybercenturion-final-tnmoc|title=National CyberCenturion Final at TNMOC {{!}} The National Museum of Computing|website=www.tnmoc.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-23}}</ref><ref name="Canada1-pass">{{cite magazine|magazine=IT World Canada|title=Facing the Canadian infosec job problem: A ‘mess and an opportunity’|first=Howard|last=Solomon|date=27 April 2016|access-date=20 September 2018|url=https://www.itworldcanada.com/article/facing-the-infosec-job-shortage-a-mess-and-an-opportunity/382715|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170811000607/https://www.itworldcanada.com/article/facing-the-infosec-job-shortage-a-mess-and-an-opportunity/382715|archive-date=11 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> in an initiative to try and build awareness for cyber security among school children.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.northropgrumman.com/CorporateResponsibility/Pages/CyberCenturion.aspx|title=CyberCenturion|website=Northrop Grumman|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-23}}</ref><ref name="HM-C-Guide">{{cite web|url=http://dera.ioe.ac.uk/22255/2/bis-15-77-Guide-to-cyber-security-schools-programmes-and-resources_Redacted.pdf|publisher=[[Government of the United Kingdom|HM Government]]|access-date=20 September 2018|title=Cyber Security - A Guide to Programmes and Resources for Schools & Further Education | dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180920105931/http://dera.ioe.ac.uk/22255/2/bis-15-77-Guide-to-cyber-security-schools-programmes-and-resources_Redacted.pdf|id=Cyber Security Challenge Schools Programme (Cyber Security Challenge)|archive-date=20 September 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== History == Cyber Centurion was set up in 2014 after the success of its US counterpart [[CyberPatriot]] and its first final took place at [[The National Museum of Computing]] on 17 April 2015.<ref name="tnmoc.org"/> The main aim of Cyber Centurion is the same as its US counterpart; to excite, educate and motivate children towards careers in STEM subjects, with an emphasis on Cyber Security.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.northropgrumman.com/MediaResources/MediaKits/CYBERUK/Documents/2017-CyberPatriotCenturion-UK.PDF|title=Cyber Patriot/Centurion Quick Facts|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref> It is also due to the large deficit in Cyber Security professionals. Northrop Grumman, the sponsors of both [[CyberPatriot]] and CyberCenturion hope that it will inspire youths towards choosing Cyber Security as a career.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.northropgrumman.com/CorporateResponsibility/Pages/CyberCenturion.aspx|title=Cyber Centurion - Northrop Grumman Corporate Responsibility|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref>
== Competition format ==
=== Tracks & Categories === CyberCenturion is split into two age categories, each with four 'tracks'.<ref name=":0" /> This is done to encourage more diversity in the competition.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cybersecuritychallenge.org.uk/competitions/cybercenturion/cybercenturion-encouraging-diversity|title=CyberCenturion: encouraging diversity - Cyber Security Challenge UK|work=Cyber Security Challenge UK|access-date=2018-09-15|language=en-US}}</ref> The younger age category is for 12-14 year olds and the older category is for 15-18 year olds.<ref name=":0" />
Within the age categories, the tracks split teams into four more groups, with a boys only track, a girls only track, a mixed team track and a cadet track.<ref name=":0" />
Places for the final are awarded in the following number of ways:
* ''"12-14 category: one place for the top team of each category (girls, boys, mixed and cadets) and the highest scoring team from all tracks combined"'' <ref name=":0" /> * ''"15-18 category: one place for the top team of each category (girls, boys, mixed and cadets) and the highest six scoring teams from all tracks combined"'' <ref name=":0" />
=== Rounds === There are four main rounds<ref name=":1">{{cite web |title=CyberCentuion V - 2018/19 Calendar |url=https://www.cybersecuritychallenge.org.uk/app/uploads/2018/08/Centurion-calendar-2018-19.pdf |website=Cyber Security Challenge UK |accessdate=2018-09-15}}</ref> with Rounds 1, 2 and 3 being online qualifying rounds where "teams will be provided with a mixture of Windows and Linux virtual machines with the aim to find and fix the vulnerabilities along with answering forensics questions".<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://alphacharlie.org.uk/cybercenturion/|title=CyberCenturion - Alpha Charlie|work=Alpha Charlie|access-date=2018-09-15|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Round 4 is the National Finals round, where qualifying teams compete face to face in London to win the top prize.<ref name=":1" />
Prior to the four main rounds, there are four other 'introductory' rounds where teams play but do not score any points.<ref name=":2" /> These are as follows:<ref name=":2" />
* Exhibition Round 1 * Exhibition Round 2 * Training Round * Practice Technical Round
=== General rules === ''"The competition is played by teams of between four and six people. Each team must include a responsible adult as the liaison between the organisers and the participants, and every team participant must be 18 years old or under when the game is played. The competition is open to anyone in Europe that meets the age requirements and has the correct team format (including leader).'' ''Each team must play a series of online qualifying rounds, which will challenge them to learn about networking, coding and cyber security. If the team scores higher than most of the other players and makes it to the leaderboard, then they will be invited to play in the National Final, a face-to-face competition which finds the ultimate champion for the year''."<ref name=":0" />
*The Qualification Competition starts as soon as the virtual image is booted and ends 6 hours later. The score is logged regularly and a live scoreboard is released during the competition to competitors. Breaching the time limit will result in penalties. * Only a single instance of the image may be opened at one time.
== Previous Winners & Finals == In CyberCenturion I, the finals were held in Block H, the original home of Colossus, of The National Museum of Computing in April 2015,<ref name="tnmoc.org" /> with KEGS Young Engineering Club at [[King Edward VI Grammar School, Chelmsford|King Edward VI Grammar School in Chelmsford]] becoming the first CyberCenturion winners and [[The Chase School]], [[Malvern, Worcestershire|Malvern]] being the runners up.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tnmoc.org/news/news-releases/cybercenturion-winners-2016-competition-given-go-ahead|title=2015 CyberCenturion Winners {{!}} The National Museum of Computing|website=www.tnmoc.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-23}}</ref><ref name="Chase2015">{{cite news|title=Chase students are cyber champions|publisher=Mazvern Gazette|url=http://www.malverngazette.co.uk/news/12913929.Chase_students_are_cyber_champions/|first=Robert|last=Hale|access-date=20 September 2018|date=25 April 2015|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171116185007/http://www.malverngazette.co.uk/news/12913929.Chase_students_are_cyber_champions/|archive-date=16 November 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In CyberCenturion II, the finals were held at The National Museum of Computing in April 2016,<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://cybersecuritychallenge.org.uk/news-events/2016-cybercenturion-winners-announced|title=2016 CyberCenturion Winners Announced - Cyber Security Challenge UK|work=Cyber Security Challenge UK|access-date=2017-04-23|language=en-US}}</ref> with "G-Sec" from Bayside Comprehensive School, Gibraltar being first-place winners, and the only team from overseas territories to currently have won Cyber Centurion.<ref name=":5" /> The top prize was technology equipment to promote help promote STEM in their school.<ref name=":3" />
In CyberCenturion III, the finals were held at the Institution of Engineering and & Technology in the Maxwell Library in April 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cybersecuritychallenge.org.uk/news-events/cyber-centurion-grand-final|title=CyberCenturionIII National Finals - Cyber Security Challenge UK|work=Cyber Security Challenge UK|access-date=2018-09-15|language=en-US}}</ref>
* The team "SPS 'B'" from St Paul’s School, London were the first-place winners, winning a selection of prizes; from books for their school, to a unique piece print of a letter from Churchill and lunch with the senior members of Northrop Grumman Corporation and Cyber Security Challenge UK.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.northropgrumman.com/news/releases/northrop-grumman-announces-winners-of-2017-cybercenturion-national-finals-to-find-cyber-security-talent-of-the-future|title=Company congratulates 2017 winners and highlights the global need for increased diversity in STEM and cyber education|work=Cyber Security Challenge UK|access-date=2017-05-28|language=en-US}}</ref> *"SPS 'A'", another team from St Paul's School, London, were also the second-place winners.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://news.northropgrumman.com/news/releases/northrop-grumman-announces-winners-of-2017-cybercenturion-national-finals-to-find-cyber-security-talent-of-the-future|title=Northrop Grumman Announces Winners of 2017 CyberCenturion National Finals to Find Cyber Security Talent of the Future|website=Northrop Grumman Newsroom|language=en|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref> *Team CyberMen, from King Edward VI Grammar School, Chelmsford, were the third-place winners.<ref name=":3" />
In CyberCenturion IV, the finals were held at the Institution of Engineering & Technology in March 2018.<ref name=":0" />
* "You really can't 'c' me", from St George’s School Edgbaston in [[Birmingham]], were the first-place winners, winning the prize of an all-expenses paid trip to the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.solihull.towntalk.co.uk/news/d/118329/birminghambased-teens-crowned-as-britains-best-codebreakers/|title=Birmingham-based teens crowned as Britain's best code-breakers, Solihull - News - Solihull TownTalk|last=|first=|date=2018-03-12|website=www.solihull.towntalk.co.uk|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref> * Second place winners were "Saved by Bell"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news-features/institution-engineering-technology/|title=The Institution of Engineering and Technology Hosts CyberCenturion 2018 Finals|last=Hill|first=Michael|date=2018-03-08|work=Infosecurity Magazine|access-date=2018-09-20}}</ref> from St Paul’s School, Barnes<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://news.northropgrumman.com/news/releases/releases-20180312-6679646|title=Northrop Grumman Announces Winners of 2018 CyberCenturion Competition to Find Diverse Cyber Security Talent of the Future|website=Northrop Grumman Newsroom|language=en|access-date=2018-09-20}}</ref> * Third place winners were "Vault 7" from Frome Collage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fromecollege.somerset.sch.uk/news-dates/archive/900-frome-college-cyber-team-placed-3rd-in-the-uk|title=Frome College cyber team placed 3rd in the UK! - Frome College|website=www.fromecollege.somerset.sch.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-09-16}}</ref> * There were also awards for top all-boys, mixed, all-girls and cadets teams.<ref name=":6" /> The all-boys team were from St. George's School Edgbaston, the mixed team were from St. Paul's School, Barnes, the all-girls team were from Bayside Comprehensive School, Gibraltar and the cadet team were from Sandbach School Combined Cadet Force.<ref name=":6" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{official|https://www.cybersecuritychallenge.org.uk/competitions/cybercenturion}}
[[Category:Computer science competitions]]

page.title: Delphic Games of the modern era

revision.comment: fix homoglyphs: convert Cyrillic characters in [С]ouncil to Latin
revision.text:
'''Delphic Games of the modern era''' involve [[presentation]]s, [[exhibition]]s, [[competition]]s and other activities in six different fields of [[art]].<ref>[http://www.delphic-games.com/downloads/flyeruk.pdf The Delphic Games of the modern era]</ref> They are inspired by the [[Delphic Games]] of [[ancient Greece]].
==Historical reference== [[image:Mousai Helikon Staatliche Antikensammlungen Schoen80 n1.jpg|left|thumb|150 px| A [[Muse]] with [[Kithara]] on Mount [[Mount Helicon]], [[Achilles Painter]] (at 440-430 BC), State collections of antiquities [[Munich]], [[Germany]]]] [[image:Delphi charioteer front DSC06255.JPG|thumb|150 px|upright|Statue of a charioteer (at 478-474 BC), Archaeological Museum [[Delphi]], [[Greece]]]] One of the four [[Panhellenic Games]] were the [[Pythian Games]] in [[Delphi]]. Held every four years, they included competitions in athletics, theatre, music, poetry, and painting to praise the god [[Apollo]], the symbol of the [[Oracle]].<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/485272/Pythian-Games Pythian Games], ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]''</ref> In the year 394 A.D., [[Theodosius I]], the emperor of the [[Byzantine Empire]] banned all Panhellenic Games as being pagan events.
Since 1912 till 1948, on the initiative of [[Pierre de Coubertin]], [[art competitions at the Summer Olympics]] were held in various countries. Medals were awarded for works related solely to [[sport]].<ref>''Richard Stanton.'' The forgotten Olympic art competitions — The story of the Olympic art competitions of the 20th century. Trafford Publishing, 2001. {{ISBN|1-55212-606-4}}</ref>
There was also an attempt to revive Pythian Games at the archeological site of Delphi, at the initiative by the Greek poet [[Angelos Sikelianos]] <ref>[http://www.salamina-online.com/aggelos_sikelianos.htm Aggelos Sikelianos]</ref> and his wife Eva Palmer. In 1927, the first Delphic Festival was held in Greece, but the revival was then abandoned.
Nowadays there are so-called Delphi Festivals, which are the closest to their Panhellenic counterparts. They include religious rituals and activities like poetry competition, religious offerings, sports and of course feasting.<ref>[http://www.greeka.com/sterea/delphi/delphi-festivals.htm Information about the Festivals of Delphi Greece]</ref> [[Image:DF-1927 copy.jpg|150px|thumb|Poster of the Delphic Festival, 1927]]
In the second half of the 20th century, there was another attempt to restore Delphic Games. Since the 1990s, representatives from Argentina, Austria, China, Cyprus, Ecuador, France, [[Germany]], Greece, Kazakhstan, Libya, Lithuania, Mexico, Nigeria, Philippines, Poland, Russia, Slovakia, and the United States came together and organized First International Delphic Games, which took place in 2000 in Moscow, Russia (before that the concept was tested out in [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], where First Junior Delphic Games took place.)
==Current revivials== Currently, there are two organizations conducting Delphic Games.
The '''[[International Delphic Council]]''' (IDC) with headquarters in Berlin was founded in 1994 at the [[Schönhausen Palace]].<ref>{{cite web| author=| date=| url=https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.392280880813927.79902.369642239744458&type=1| title=Foundation of the IDC| publisher=// facebook.com| accessdate=2014-07-03}}</ref> Since 1995 the IDC actively supports the creation of the National Delphic organizations.<ref>{{cite web| author=| date=| url=https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.386038754771473.78926.369642239744458&type=1| title=Foundation of the NDC Nigeria| publisher=// facebook.com| accessdate=2014-07-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author=| date=| url=https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.384951174880231.78728.369642239744458&type=1| title=Foundation of the "Delphic Movement in Russia"| publisher=// facebook.com| accessdate=2014-07-03}}</ref> Since 1997 the IDC has organized the International Youth Delphic Games in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], Germany, Philippines, South Africa, as well as, since 2000, the International Delphic Games for adult participants in Russia, Malaysia, South Korea.<ref>''Lee Kyung-min''.[http://www.koreaittimes.com/story/4908/top-artists-gather-3rd-jeju-delphic-games Top Artists to Gather at 3rd Jeju Delphic Games] September 7th, 2009</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |date= |url=http://delphic.org/english/03games/chronology.htm |title=Delphic Games |publisher=// delphic.org |accessdate=2014-07-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141102191231/http://delphic.org/english/03games/chronology.htm |archivedate=2014-11-02 |df= }}</ref> The IDC held Delphic Games and Junior Delphic Games in the four-year cycle, two years offset from one another, such as the Olympic Games, held at different locations in the world.<ref>{{cite web| author=| date=| url=http://www.kulturserver.de/-/organisationen/detail/52021| title=International Delphic Council| publisher=// kulturserver.de| accessdate=2014-07-03|language=de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author=| date=| url=http://www.virtualmarket.itb-berlin.de/?Action=showCompany&id=57634| title=International Delphic Council: ITB Berlin Virtual Market Place| publisher=// virtualmarket.itb-berlin.de| accessdate=2014-07-03}}</ref> The International Delphic Games and Congresses receive greetings, patronage and support from various international organizations and celebrities.<ref>{{cite web| author=| date=| url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=392267214148627&set=a.392265017482180.79897.369642239744458&type=1&theater| title=The letter with the greeting message from the Council of Europe| publisher=// facebook.com| accessdate=2014-07-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author=| date=| url=https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.387774587931223.79201.369642239744458&type=1| title=2nd Delphic World Congress| publisher=// facebook.com| accessdate=2014-07-03}}</ref>
A newer organization, '''[[International Delphic Committee]]''' (IDC) with headquarters in Moscow, was registered in 2004.<ref>[http://www.idcworld.ru/news.list?year=2006&lang=en Opening of the website of the International Delphic Committee]</ref> It organizes International Delphic Games, Youth Delphic Games of Russia and Youth Delphic Games of [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]]. Since 2005 the Junior Delphic Games in Russia and the Junior Delphic Games in [[Commonwealth of Independent States]] are conducted by the International Delphic Committee. These Junior Delphic Games are dedicated to significant domestic events.<ref>[http://www.vesti.ru/doc.html?id=355094 The Ninth Junior Delphic Games Russia dedicated to the anniversary of the victory] // Вести.ру - 23 апреля 2010</ref><ref>[http://youth.minstm.gov.ru/102/104.shtml/xPages/entry.2963.html Welcoming words of the Minister V.L. Mutko] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309092347/http://youth.minstm.gov.ru/102/104.shtml/xPages/entry.2963.html |date=2012-03-09 }}</ref> This International Delphic Committee conducted also in September 2008 the Second International Delphic Games in [[Saratov]] / [[Russia]], but some Saratov Sunday editions and news portals questioned the status and legitimacy of the games.<ref>[http://old.om-saratov.ru/news/index.php?ELEMENT_ID=2388 The newspaper "Vremya" questions the status of the Delphic Games]// «Время» Саратов, 22.09.2008</ref><ref>[http://news.sarbc.ru/analytics/2008/09/29/83746.html "Press Menu". Delphic Games: spoon of honey in a barrel of tar] // СаратовБизнесКонсалтинг, 29 сентября 2008</ref>
Under the patronage of the International Delphic Committee (headquartered in Moscow) and [[UNESCO]],{{Citation needed|date=July 2014|reason=please give a reliable source for this assertion.}}<ref>[http://astana.gov.kz/en/modules/material/4923?lang=en Kazakhstan's national team won the 2nd team place at the International Delphic Games]// Official Site of Akimat of Astana (Republic of Kazakhstan)</ref><ref>[http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2014/5/6/kyrgyz_gymnast_wins_3rd_place_at.htm?lang=ru&lang=en Kyrgyz gymnast wins 3rd place at European Youth Delphic Games] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531124251/http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2014/5/6/kyrgyz_gymnast_wins_3rd_place_at.htm?lang=ru&lang=en |date=2014-05-31 }}// News Agency «HispanicBusiness» (CA, USA)</ref> the First Open Youth European Delphic Games were held in [[Volgograd]], Russia, on May 2–7, 2014.<ref>{{cite web| author=| url=http://v102.ru/society/44616.html| title=Дельфийские игры обошлись бюджету Волгоградской области почти в 100 миллионов рублей| accessdate=2014-07-03}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.delphic-games.com/ The official site of the IDC Berlin (Council)] * [http://www.delphic-games.com/english/03games/chronology.htm Chronology of the Delphic Games (according to IDC Berlin)] * [http://www.delphic-media.com/link__www_artsight_de_.html Delphic-Media] * [http://www.idcworld.org The official site of the IDC Moscow (Committee)] * [http://delphic.ru/menu/gmap.asp?0402 Chronology of Delphic Games (according to NDC Russia)]

revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event |name = East Cork Early Music Festival |logo = [[File:Eastcorkearlymusicfestival.png|220px]] |caption = |genre = [[Early music]] festival |location = [[East Cork]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] |years_active = 2003-present |frequency = Annual |dates = |attendance = |patron = |website = [http://www.eastcorkearlymusic.ie/ eastcorkearlymusic.ie] }} '''East Cork Early Music Festival''' is an Irish [[arts festival]] that is intended to "promote the performance and appreciation" of music written before 1750 on [[period instruments]].<ref name="about">{{cite web|url = http://www.eastcorkearlymusic.ie/about/ | publisher = eastcorkearlymusic.ie | title = About - East Cork Early Music Festival | accessdate = 13 October 2018 }}</ref> Formed in 2003 under the artistic direction of Sarah Cunningham, the festival takes place in the [[East Cork]] area during the autumn (usually at the beginning of October).<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.irishtimes.com/news/never-too-late-for-a-little-early-music-1.1157203 | publisher = Irish Times | title = Never too late for a little early music | date = 11 September 2004 | accessdate = 13 October 2018 }}</ref> It features concerts, lectures, workshops and other events related to [[early music]].<ref name="thecork">{{cite web|url = https://www.thecork.ie/2017/10/12/cork-cobh-kinsale-feature-at-east-cork-early-music-festival/ | publisher = TheCork.ie | title = Cork, Cobh and Kinsale feature at East Cork Early Music Festival | date = 12 October 2017 | accessdate = 13 October 2018 }}</ref>
East Cork Early Music Festival has included events in local landmark buildings such as [[Saint Fin Barre's Cathedral|St. Fin Barre’s Cathedral]], [[Fota House]], the [[Ballymaloe House|Grainstore at Ballymaloe]], the [[Collegiate Church of St Mary Youghal|Collegiate Church in Youghal]] and [[Cloyne Cathedral]].<ref name="corkman">{{cite web|url = https://www.independent.ie/regionals/corkman/entertainment/east-promises-best-feastival-yet-27072180.html | publisher = Independent News & Media | title = East promises best 'feastival' yet | date = 27 August 2009 | accessdate = 13 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.irishexaminer.com/lifestyle/artsfilmtv/east-cork-early-music-festival-dont-be-late-290300.html | publisher = Irish Examiner | title = East Cork Early Music Festival: Don’t be late | date = 8 October 2014 | accessdate = 13 October 2018 }}</ref> Other events have taken place in the Curtis Auditorium and Stack Theatre in the [[Cork School of Music]].<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.independent.ie/regionals/corkman/entertainment/east-cork-early-music-festival-is-best-in-the-land-27087093.html | publisher = Independent News & Media | title = East Cork Early Music Festival is best in the land | date = 1 September 2011 | accessdate = 13 October 2018 }}</ref> In October 2017, the festival established a partnership with Nano Nagle Place, with some concerts taking place at this venue.<ref>{{citeweb |url=https://www.thecork.ie/2018/07/31/nano-nagle-place-and-east-cork-early-music-festival-enter-a-musical-partnership/|title=Nano Nagle Place and East Cork Early Music Festival enter a musical partnership | publisher = TheCork.ie | date = 31 July 2018 | accessdate = 13 October 2018 }}</ref>
A number of Irish and international performers have appeared at the festival,<ref name="corkman"/> including [[Emma Kirkby]], [[Rachel Podger]], [[Barthold Kuijken|Barthold]] and [[Wieland Kuijken]], [[James Bowman (musician)|James Bowman]], [[Rachel Brown (flautist)|Rachel Brown]], the [[Irish Baroque Orchestra]], and [[Bob van Asperen]].<ref name="about"/><ref name="thecork"/><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.irishtimes.com/culture/a-passionate-voice-for-early-music-1.488887 | publisher = Irish Times | title = A passionate voice for early music | date = 6 September 2005 | accessdate = 15 October 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.irishexaminer.com/lifestyle/artsfilmtv/artsvibe/goy-sets-early-music-standard-210332.html | publisher = Irish Examiner | title = Goy sets early music standard | date = 10 October 2012 | accessdate = 15 October 2018 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{official|http://www.eastcorkearlymusic.ie}} {{Classical music festival}} [[Category:Classical music festivals in Ireland]] [[Category:Arts festivals in Ireland]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2003]] [[Category:Early music festivals]] [[Category:Music festivals established in 2003]] [[Category:Autumn events in the Republic of Ireland]]

{{Infobox Song Contest |name = Eurovision Young Dancers | year = 2013 |size = 250px |logo = Eurovision Young Dancers 2013 logo.jpg |final = 14 June 2013 |presenters = Tomasz Kammel |exsupervisor = [[Vladislav Yakovlev (television executive)|Vladislav Yakovlev]] |exproducer = Robert Kamyk |host = [[Telewizja Polska]] (TVP) |venue = [[Baltic State Opera|Baltic Opera House]], [[Gdańsk]], [[Poland]]{{cite web|url=http://www3.ebu.ch/cms/en/sites/ebu/contents/frontpage-news/news-2012/gdansk-to-host-eurovision-young.html|title=GDANSK TO HOST EUROVISION YOUNG DANCERS|publisher=''[[EBU]]''|date= 2012-10-01 |accessdate= 2012-10-04}} |windance = {{Esc|Netherlands|Dancers}}
[[Sedrig Verwoert]] |vote = Three professional juries choose the top 2 performances, and after the final battle, they choose the winner dancer. |entries = 10 |debut = {{ubl|{{Esc|Belarus|Dancers}}}} |return = {{ubl|{{Esc|Armenia|Dancers}}|{{Esc|Czech Republic|Dancers}}|{{Esc|Ukraine|Dancers}}}} |withdraw = {{ubl|{{Esc|Croatia|Dancers}}|{{Esc|Greece|Dancers}}|{{Esc|Kosovo|Dancers}}|{{Esc|Portugal|Dancers}}}} |null = |interval = | Green = Y | Green SA = | Purple = | Red = Y | Red2 = Did not qualify to the final round | Yellow = Y }} The '''Eurovision Young Dancers 2013''' was the thirteenth edition of the [[Eurovision Young Dancers]], held at the [[Baltic State Opera|Baltic Opera House]] in [[Gdańsk]], [[Poland]] on 14 June 2013.{{cite web|title=Eurovision Young Dancers 2013: About the show|url=http://www.youngdancers.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=1703#About|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=5 October 2014}} Organised by the [[European Broadcasting Union]] (EBU) and host broadcaster [[Telewizja Polska]] (TVP), dancers from ten countries participated in the televised final. {{Esccnty|Belarus|Dancers}} made their début while {{Esccnty|Armenia|Dancers}}, {{Esccnty|Czech Republic|Dancers}} and {{Esccnty|Ukraine|Dancers}} returned. Four countries withdrew from the contest. The event is aimed at young dancers aged between 16 and 21, competing in modern dances, be it solo or in couples, as long as they were not professionally engaged. [[Sedrig Verwoert]] of the Netherlands won the contest, with Felix Berning of Germany placing second (runner-up).{{cite web|title=Eurovision Young Dancers 2013: Participants|url=http://www.youngdancers.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=1703#Participants|website=youngmusicians.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=5 October 2014}} ==Location== {{details|topic=the host venue|Baltic State Opera}} [[File:DanzigBaltischeStaatsoper.jpg|left|thumb|Baltic Opera House]] The chosen venue by the host broadcaster [[Telewizja Polska|TVP]] was the Baltic Opera House in [[Gdańsk]]. The stage was designed by Michał Białousz.{{cite web|url=http://www.youngdancers.tv/page/news?id=presenting_the_2013_stage|title=Presenting de 2013 Stage|publisher=''[[EBU]]''|accessdate= 2013-06-09}} ==Format== The format consists of dancers who are non-[[professional]] and between the ages of 16–21, competing in a performance of dance routines of their choice, which they have prepared in advance of the competition. All of the acts then take part in a choreographed [[group dance]] during 'Young Dancers Week'.{{cite web|title=Eurovision Young Dancers - Format|url=http://www.youngdancers.tv/page/pilsen-2015/about/format|website=youngdancers.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=8 March 2015}} ==Jury panel== [[Jury|Jury members]] of a professional aspect and representing the elements of [[ballet]], [[Contemporary dance|contemporary]], and [[Modern dance|modern]] dancing styles, score each of the competing individual and group dance routines. Once all the jury votes have been counted, the two participants which received the highest total of points progress to a final round. The final round consists of a 90-second 'dual', were each of the finalists perform a 45-second random dance-off routine. The overall winner upon completion of the final dances is chosen by the professional jury members. The jury members consisted of the following: * {{flagu|Poland}} – Krzysztof Pastor * {{flagu|Germany}} – Nadia Espiritu * {{flagu|New Zealand}}/{{flagu|United Kingdom}} – Cameron McMillan ==Participants== The performance order was agreed by the [[Ballet Boyz]], and approved by the chair of the EBU Steering Group on 10 June 2013.{{cite web|url=https://youngdancers.tv/story/running-order-decided|title=Running order decided|website=youngdancers.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|date=10 June 2013|accessdate=5 February 2018}} ===Results=== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Draw ! Country ! Participant ! Dance ! Choreographer ! {{Other uses}} {{Redirect|Funfair||Funfair (disambiguation)}} {{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=September 2013}} {{lead too short|date=February 2016}} }}
[[File:2008Overview1.JPG|thumb|A trade fair for the travel industry]] [[File:Fairgames.jpg|thumb|A boy at the fish pond, the Rockton World's Fair, harvest festival, Canada, 2010]] A '''fair''' (archaic: '''faire''' or '''fayre'''), also known as a '''funfair''', is a gathering of people for a variety of entertainment or commercial activities. It is normally of the essence of a fair that it is temporary with scheduled times lasting from an afternoon to several weeks.
==Types== [[File:Goose Fair Roundabout.jpg|thumb|right|Roundabouts (also known as a carousel or merry-go-round) are traditional attractions, often seen at fairs]] Variations of fairs include: * [[Street fair]], a fair that celebrates the character of a neighborhood and merchant oriented, (as the word 'fair' is historically defined; that being a marketplace). As its name suggests, it is usually held on the main street of a neighborhood. * [[Fête]], an elaborate festival, party, or celebration. * [[Festival]], an event ordinarily coordinated and/or celebrated by a community or group with a theme e.g. music, art, season and/or on some characteristic(s) or aspect(s) of a community, or the region i.e beach, snow, local harvest, etc. or state the community is in. This can include a tradition, history, an prevalent ethnicity, religion, or a national holiday, e.g. The Fourth of July. * [[County fair]] or [[agricultural show]], a public event exhibiting the equipment, animals, sports and recreation associated with agriculture and animal husbandry. * [[State fair]], an annual competitive and recreational gathering of a U.S. state's population, usually held in late summer or early fall. It is a larger version of a county fair, often including only exhibits or competitors that have won in their categories at the more local county fairs. * [[Trade fair]], an exhibition organized so that companies in a specific industry can showcase and demonstrate their latest products and services, study activities of rivals, and examine recent market trends and opportunities. * [[Traveling carnival]], usually simply called a carnival, an amusement show made up of amusement rides, food vendors, merchandise vendors, games of chance and skill, thrill acts, and animal acts. * [[Traveling funfair]], a small to medium-sized traveling show primarily composed of stalls and other amusements.
==History== [[File:1590 Mostaert Dorfkirmes anagoria.JPG|thumb|''Village fair'' by Flemish artist [[Gillis Mostaert]] 1590]] [[File:Delaware State Fair 2009.jpg|thumb|Fairs can include exhibitions of animals, and before competitions, the animals will be groomed by their owners]] [[File:Rosa bonheur horse fair 1835 55.jpg|thumb|''[[The Horse Fair]]'', painting by [[Rosa Bonheur]] (1852-1855)]] The [[Roman Empire|Roman]] fairs were [[holiday]]s on which there was an intermission of labour and pleadings.{{clarify|date=June 2015}} In the Roman provinces of [[Judea (Roman province)|Judea]] and [[Syria Palaestina]], Jewish rabbis prohibited Jews from participating in fairs in certain towns because the religious nature of the fairs contravened the prescribed practice of Judaism.<ref name="Schäfer2002">{{cite book |last=Schäfer |first=Peter |title=The Talmud Yerushalmi and Graeco-Roman Culture |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_J5bdHyPprIC&pg=PA448 |accessdate=8 June 2015 |year=2002 |publisher=Mohr Siebeck |isbn=9783161478529 |pages=448–}}</ref>
In the [[Middle Ages]], many fairs developed as temporary markets and were especially important for long-distance and international trade, as wholesale traders travelled, sometimes for many days, to fairs where they could be sure to meet those they needed to buy from or sell to. Fairs were usually tied to a special [[Christian]] religious occasions, such as the Saint's day of the local church. Stagshaw in England, is documented to have held annual fairs as early as 1293 consisting of the sales of animals. Along with the main fair held on 4 July, the city also hosted smaller fairs throughout the year where specific types of animals were sold, such as one for horses, one for lambs, and one for ewes.<ref name="NorderhaugThompson2006">{{cite book |last1=Norderhaug |first1=Jennifer |last2=Thompson |first2=Jennifer Norderhaug & Barbara |title=Walking the Northumbria Dales: Un |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yr8AZrod3O4C&pg=PA63 |accessdate=8 June 2015 |date=2006-08-01 |publisher=Sigma Press |isbn=9781850588382 |pages=63–}}</ref>
The [[Kumbh Mela]], held every twelve years, at [[Allahabad]], [[Haridwar]], [[Nashik]], and [[Ujjain]] is one of the largest fairs in India, where more than 60 million people gathered in January 2001, making it the [[List of largest gatherings in history|largest gathering]] anywhere in the world.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6226895.stm Millions bathe at Hindu festival] ''[[BBC News]]'', January 3, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/1137833.stm Kumbh Mela pictured from space - probably the largest human gathering in history] ''[[BBC News]]'', January 26, 2001.</ref><ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/travel/travel_images/article3597725.ece Kumbh Mela: the largest pilgrimage - Pictures: Kumbh Mela by Karoki Lewis] ''[[The Times]]'', March 22, 2008.</ref> ''[[Kumbha]]'' means a pitcher and ''Mela'' means ''fair'' in Sanskrit.
In the United States, fairs draw in as many as 150 million people each summer.<ref name=VonDrehle>{{cite journal |last=Von Drehle |first=David |others=Photographs by Greg Miller |date=2007-07-23 |title=A new Day at the Fair |journal=Time |volume=170 |issue=4 |pages=50 |issn=0040-781X }}</ref> Children's competitions at an American fair range from breeding small animals to robotics, whilst the organization [[4-H]] has become a traditional association.<ref name=VonDrehle/>
==Legacy==
===Legal implications=== {{See also|Court of Piepowders}} Because of the great numbers of people attracted by fairs they were often the scenes of riots and disturbances, so the privilege of holding a fair was granted by [[royal charter]]. At first, they were allowed only in towns and places of strength, or where there was a bishop, sheriff or governor who could keep order. In time various benefits became attached to certain fairs, such as granting people the protection of a holiday and allowing them freedom from arrest in certain circumstances. The officials were authorized to mete out justice to those who came to their fair; eventually even the smallest fair would have had a court to adjudicate on offences and disputes arising within the fairground, called a ''pye powder'' court (from [[Old French]] ''pieds pouldres'', literally "dusty feet", meaning an itinerant trader, from [[Medieval Latin]] ''pedes pulverosi'').
===In art and language=== The chaotic nature of the Stagshaw Bank Fair with masses of people and animals and stalls inspired the Newcastle colloquialism "like a Stagey Bank Fair" to describe a general mess.<ref name="NorderhaugThompson2006"/>
The American [[county fair]] is featured in [[E. B. White]]'s ''[[Charlotte's Web]]''.<ref name=VonDrehle/>
==See also== * [[Art exhibition]] * [[Lists of festivals]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite EB1911|wstitle=Fair |volume=10 |short=x}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Use British English|date=March 2012}} {{coord|51|30|43|N|0|4|9|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}}
'''The Garrick Theatre''', also known as ''Garrick's Subscription'' was a small theatre located in Leman St, [[Whitechapel]]. The theatre opened in 1831, and closed in about 1881. The theatre was named for the actor, [[David Garrick]], who had made his début at the nearby [[Goodman's Fields Theatre]] on 9 October 1741, playing the role of ''[[Richard III (play)|Richard III]]''.
The performance on 11 May 1840 was ''Marie!'' and ''Virginius the Rum’un!'', from an existent playbill.<ref>[http://www.library.ex.ac.uk/special/guides/archives/141-150/149_01.html Collection of University of Exeter] accessed 4 Mar 2007</ref> The plays were probably [[melodramas]] and some indication of the fare available at the time.
The first theatre burned down in 1846, and was rebuilt to open as ''The Albert and Garrick Royal Amphitheatre''. During rebuilding from 1852-1854, the neighbour, a gun manufacturer, obtained an injunction against the proprietor, Lawrence Levy, to restrict the height of the adjacent wall so as not to impede light to his premises.<ref>The Times 30 July 1852 page 6 and 24 March 1854 page 11</ref> The theatre was managed by Lawrence Levy from 1854 until 1864. He returned to manage the theatre between 1867 and 1868. In 1856 E.B. Gaston was Stage Manager.<ref>[http://library.kent.ac.uk/library/special/icons/playbills/londonindex2.htm University of Kent - Playbill collection] accessed 4 Mar 2007</ref> The second theatre had a capacity of 462, although when Lawrence Levy put the theatre up for sale in 1866-1868, he claimed it "will hold 1,600 persons" and "can be made to hold 2,500", and then in 1868 was claiming "Was built for a circus" and "Holds 1,700 persons; can be made for 8,000".<ref>Advertisements in The Era, e.g. 1 July 1866, 6 January 1867, 2 February 1868</ref>
A young [[Barney Barnato]] is reputed to have begged pass outs from theatre leavers, to sell them on to others for a halfpenny<ref>[http://www.mainlesson.com/display.php?author=colvin&book=rhodes&story=barnato&PHPSESSID=8675b0a125391c6bd735a4fa57971f8d Rhodes and Barnato - in ''Cecil Rhodes'' by Ian D. Colvin] accessed 4 Mar 2007</ref>
After actor-manager J. B. Howe's [[bankruptcy]] in 1875, the theatre remained empty until 1879. Actress-manageress May Bulmer then ran the theatre until it was demolished, having a personal success in the light opera ''A Cruise to China''.<ref>[http://www.victorianweb.org/mt/theaters/pva234.html Victorian Web - Theatres in Victorian London] accessed 5 Mar 2007</ref> Although Lawrence Levy had died in 1873, the theatre was still part of his estate in 1882 when his trustee testified at the Old Bailey in the trial of two men called Culver and Jacobs. They had been claiming to hold the lease of the theatre, and had fraudulently been taking payments from actors on the promise of providing them with engagements.<ref>Proceedings of the Old Bailey 26-6-1882.</ref> The site of the theatre is today occupied by the old Leman Street Police Station, built in 1891.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=May 2018}} {{Primary sources|date=May 2018}}}} {{infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = High Sierra Music Festival | image = [[Image:HSMFlogo.jpg|250px]] | location = [[Quincy, California]], United States | years_active= 1991–present | genre = [[Jamband]], [[newgrass]], [[funk]], [[jazz]], others | dates = First weekend of July, preceding Thursday and Friday | website = {{URL|www.highsierramusic.com}} }} '''High Sierra Music Festival''' is a multi-day [[music festival]] held in [[Quincy, California]], United States, a mountainous area about 80 miles northwest of [[Reno, Nevada]]. The festival is held each year the weekend of July 4. The four-day festival features an eclectic mix of some of the most famous national and international names in [[jamband]], [[newgrass]] and [[funk]]. Other represented genres include [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[roots rock]], [[electronica]], [[reggae]], [[jazz]] and [[afrobeat]]. Away from the music stages, patrons can attend films and movement playshops - yoga, pilates, etc., shop for arts and crafts, or enjoy a wide variety of gourmet food and drink. It's a family friendly and community oriented event with an expanding Family Area full of activities and certified nannies available throughout the weekend. The first High Sierra Music Festival was in 1991, and was the genesis of High Sierra Music, of Berkeley, California. The organization has also produced festivals and concerts elsewhere in California, and in Maryland, Nevada, Georgia, Massachusetts, and Missouri. Past artists{{cite web |url=http://highsierramusic.com/past-lineups/ |title=High Sierra Music Festival Past Lineups |author= |website=Highsierramusic.com |access-date=24 September 2017}} have included [[The Black Crowes]], [[Bob Weir]] & [[RatDog]], [[Michael Franti|Michael Franti & Spearhead]], [[Béla Fleck and the Flecktones]], [[Bruce Hornsby]], [[The String Cheese Incident]], [[Nickel Creek]], [[Moe (band)|moe.]], [[Widespread Panic]], [[Medeski Martin & Wood]], [[Yonder Mountain String Band]], [[Gov't Mule]], [[John Butler Trio]], [[Umphrey's McGee]], [[My Morning Jacket]], [[Les Claypool]], [[Leftover Salmon]], and [[The Slip (band)|The Slip]] (the only band to play the festival 12 consecutive years). ==Yearly lineups== ===28th Annual: July 5–9, 2018, Quincy, California=== {{cite web |url=https://2018highsierramusicfestival.sched.com/directory/speakers |title=2018 High Sierra Music Festival Artists |author= |website=highsierramusic.com |access-date=20 August 2018}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox Theatre |name = Konpira Grand Theatre
金毘羅大芝居 |image = KyuKonpiraooshibai.jpg |caption = The front of the Konpira Grand Theatre |address = 香川県仲多度郡琴平町乙１２４１
1241 Kotohira-chō, Nakatado District, Kagawa Prefecture |city = [[Kotohira, Kagawa|Kotohira]], [[Kagawa Prefecture]] |country = {{flagicon|Japan}} [[Japan]] |designation = [[Important Cultural Properties of Japan|Important Cultural Property]] |coordinates = {{coord|34.184633|133.818028|type:landmark|display=inline}} |architect = |owner = Kotohira-chō Shikoku Konpira Kabuki Grand Theatre Promotion Association |capacity = 1000-1200Leiter. p72. |type = Kabuki theater |opened = 1836Leiter. p60. |yearsactive = |rebuilt = |closed = |othernames = Kanamaru-za (金丸座) |production = |currentuse = |website = http://www.konpirakabuki.jp/index.html }} The '''Konpira Grand Theatre''' (金毘羅大芝居 ''Konpira Ōshibai''), also known as the '''Kanamaru-za''' (金丸座) is a restored [[Kabuki]] theatre in [[Kotohira, Kagawa|Kotohira]], [[Kagawa Prefecture|Kagawa]], on the island of [[Shikoku]], [[Japan]]. It was originally constructed in 1835,[http://www.bunka.go.jp/bunkazai/shurui/juubun_ken_shoukai/036.html Agency for Cultural Affairs]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (in Japanese)[http://www.jsme.or.jp/tsd/ICBTT/conference02/UzuhikoTSUBOI.html Historical Development of Revolving Stages of Theaters Invented in Japan - Improvement by Adoption of European Culture] by Uzuhiko TSUBOI for the 1st International Conference on Business and Technology transfer (ICBTT200) and is the oldest kabuki theatre in Japan."Kanamaruza." [http://www2.ntj.jac.go.jp/dglib/edc_dic/dictionary/dic_ka/dic_ka_13.html Kabuki Encyclopedia] (歌舞伎事典, ''kabuki jiten''). Japan Arts Council, 2001-2003. Accessed 5 October 2008. Kabuki plays are performed for one month each year, usually in April."Kanamaruza." [http://kabuki21.com/kanamaruza.php Kabuki21.com]. Accessed 5 October 2008. ==History== The theatre was originally built in 1835 and 1836, and takes its name from the nearby [[Kompira Shrine]] which is in turn named after the Hindu/Buddhist deity [[Kumbhira]] to which the shrine is dedicated.Leiter. p57. Prior to its construction, small temporary theatres were frequently built on the site, and doubled as lottery halls.Leiter. p58. The design was based on that of the [[Ōnishi Theatre]] of [[Osaka]], and the construction costs, amounting to roughly 1000 ''[[ryō]]'', were raised by the local [[geisha]] community.Leiter. p61. The theatre was originally controlled by the [[Kanemitsu-in]], a local Buddhist temple, but in 1877 came to be owned by a man by the name of Kyōhō, an ''[[otokodate]]'', wealthy merchant, gang leader, and head of the local fire brigade. He changed the name of the theatre to the Inari-za (named after the Shintō deity [[Inari (mythology)|Inari]]), and ran full-day programs as many other major theatres throughout the country began to cut down and only show selected scenes for a few hours a day. The theatre was purchased in 1897 by a man by the name of Kawazoe Sadaji, who changed its name to Chitose-za (One Thousand Years Theatre), and sold it three years later. Kanamaru Genjirō thus obtained the theater in 1900, for 4500 [[yen]], and renamed it once again, to the Kanamaru-za, a name which continues to be used today.Leiter. pp62-3. After falling into disuse for many years, and being used as a movie theater for some time, the theatre was designated an [[Important Cultural Properties of Japan|Important Cultural Property]] by the [[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] of the national government in 1970, after having been designated as such by the prefecture in 1953. Following a fund-raising drive which raised over US$2 million, the theatre was restored in 1976 to its [[Edo period]] appearance and moved some 200 meters to a new location. In late June 1985, a troupe led by [[Nakamura Kichiemon II]] and [[Sawamura Sōjūrō IX]] performed the play ''[[Saikai Zakura Misome no Kiyomizu]]'' ("Reunion Amongst the Cherry Blossoms After the First Meeting at Kiyomizu") and dance drama ''[[Niwakajishi]]'' ("Spirited Lion"), at the Kanamaru-za, in a three-day stint following performances at the [[Naka-za]] in Osaka.Leiter. pp88-89. Kichiemon was impressed with the theatre's atmosphere and traditional design and amenities, and encouraged other actors to journey to Kotohira. A month-long program has been produced every spring since, featuring major Tokyo/Osaka actors. Much of the 1995 film ''[[Sharaku (film)|Sharaku]]'', set in 1790s [[Edo]] and revolving around the life of ''[[ukiyo-e]]'' artist [[Sharaku]], was filmed at the Konpira Theatre, which stood in for the no longer extant [[Nakamura-za]].Leiter. p56. ==Architecture== [[File:Former Konpira-ooshibai01n3999.jpg|thumb|Exterior of the Konpira Grand theatre]] The structure's frontage is about 80 feet long, or 13 ''ken'' and 2 ''[[Shaku (unit)|shaku]]'' in the now no longer used [[Japanese units of measurement|traditional Japanese units of measurement]]. During the month when kabuki actors journey down from Tokyo or [[Kamigata]] (the Kyoto-Osaka area) and perform at the theatre, large banners bearing the crest of the [[Shōchiku]] company, and signboards with the stars' names are displayed. Fake bushels of rice, representing gifts from fans and sponsors, are also situated outside the theatre. There are three entrances into the building. The ones on the left and right are of normal size, but the central entrance, called the {{nihongo|"mouse door"|ねずみ木戸|nezumi kido}}, is quite small and requires one to crouch in order to enter. This was an effective form of crowd control in the Edo period, and, along with armed guards, helped prevent anyone from entering without a ticket.Leiter. p64. While the average commoner playgoer had to use this small ''nezumi kido'', those associated with the Kanemitsu-in used the ''goyō kido'' on the right. The large ''ōkido'' on the left was used by members of the samurai class, and others of importance.Leiter. p65. One of the primary features distinguishing the renovated Konpira Grand Theatre other kabuki theatres in Japan today, which are more modern in style, is the ''[[tatami]]'' floor in the main (orchestra section) seating section. Areas of seating for small parties are divided from one another by a grid of wooden planking, into box seats called ''[[masu (Japanese)|masu]]''; sitting this way allows greater range of motion for the viewer, and thus allows one to more easily turn to watch action on the ''[[hanamichi]]'', the long stage extension which runs from the stage to the back of the theater.Leiter. p67,69. A raised ''tatami'' platform called the ''sajiki'' runs along the left side of the theatre on both the ground and second floors; these were traditionally the most expensive seats, and still are today.Leiter. pp67-8. A similar section which runs along the right side of the theatre is called the ''demago'', though traditionally this would have been called the ''takadoma'' in Edo.Leiter. pp72,77. Another distinguishing feature is the ''karaido'', or "empty well", a space between the ''hanamichi'' and stage accessible from underneath by stairs; while most other theatres utilize an elevator trap called a ''suppon'' ("snapping turtle") to allow actors to enter directly onto the ''hanamichi'', the stairs allow an actor to better time his entrance, for better dramatic effect.Leiter. p71. The Konpira Grand Theatre has a ''suppon'' as well, but scholar [[Samuel Leiter]] writes that he is unaware of another active theatre which uses a ''karaido''. A second ''hanamichi'', called the ''kari hanamichi'' and about half the width of the main ''hanamichi'', runs through the theatre towards the right side; a connecting plank is sometimes used to allow actors to cross between the two ''hanamichi'' at some distance from the stage.Leiter. p77. Much of the left and right walls of the seating area are composed of ''[[shōji]]'' panels, which can be slid like sliding doors to provide access to corridors which run outside the seating area. The outermost side walls of the theatre building, forming the opposite side of these corridors, consist of rain shutters known as ''madobuta'' ("window lids") or ''akarimado'' ("lighting windows") which can be raised and lowered by stagehands to let the sunlight in and control the lighting of the theatre, in order to create atmospheric effects, such as a dark and spooky atmosphere for certain elements of ghost plays. There are areas for musicians on both stage left and right, along with a second-story room above stage left, called the ''yuka'', used specifically by ''tayū'' (narrative chanters) and [[shamisen]] players heard in plays deriving from the ''[[jōruri (music)|jōruri]]'' puppet theatre. This is in contrast to the theatres of Tokyo and Kamigata, which traditionally have boxes for the musicians on only one side of the stage (stage right and left respectively).Leiter. p79. The stage itself is about half the width of that in the modern theatres; while the stage opening at [[Kabuki-za]] in Tokyo is nearly ninety feet wide, the space between the supporting pillars at the Kanamaru-za is eight ''ken'', or roughly 48 feet; Leiter calls the larger scale of the more modern theatres a loss and an artistic weakening, as theatres moved "away from the most effective means for expressing theatrical art." The Kanamaru-za also boasts a manually operated rotating stage (''mawari butai'') and trap doors (''seri''),[http://www.town.kotohira.kagawa.jp/english/kabuki/history/index.html www.town.kotohira.kagawa.jp] accessed 27 September 2007 though the "hell" (''naraku'') area underneath the stage from which these were operated was considered by many actors so unpleasant that it would often be avoided in favor of the corridors outside the ''sajiki'' (along the sides of the theatre) as a means for traveling around the theatre.Leiter. p81. ==References== {{Commons category|Kanamaruza (Kyū Konpira Ōshibai)}} *Leiter, Samuel. "The Kanamaru-za: Japan's Oldest ''Kabuki'' Theatre." ''[[Asian Theatre Journal]]'', vol. 14, no. 1 (Spring 1997). University of Hawai'i Press. pp56–92. {{reflist|colwidth=33em}} [[Category:Kabuki theatres]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Kagawa Prefecture]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1836]] [[Category:Important Cultural Properties of Japan]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Kagawa Prefecture]]

page.title: List of battles and other violent events by death toll

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove article|date=July 2008}} {{Globalize|date=August 2012}}}} This page lists mortalities from battles and individual military operations or acts of violence, sorted by death toll. For wars and events more extensive in scope, see ''[[List of wars and disasters by death toll]]''. For natural disasters, see ''[[List of natural disasters by death toll]]''. {{dynamic list}} ==Battles and sieges== ''Many of the entries in this section are currently for total casualties rather than deaths. Until this notice is removed, check the individual links to confirm what the figure represents.'' {{Main|List of battles by casualties}} ==Bombing campaigns== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 146-1994-041-07, Dresden, zerstörtes Stadtzentrum.jpg|thumb|Dresden after being bombed]] ===World War II=== * Around 43,000 – Allied airforce bombing of Hamburg (''[[Bombing of Hamburg in World War II|Operation Gomorrah]]'') during the period 24 July 1943 and 31 July 1943 * Maximum 25,000 (minimum 22,700) – Allied airforce [[bombing of Dresden]] during the period 7 October 1944 to 7 April 1945[http://www.sz-online.de/nachrichten/mobil.asp?action=ShowArticle&nar_id=2438444&kdhash=%20hier%20die%20Online-Ausgabe Sächsische Zeitung (Saxonian Newspaper), April 15, 2010: ''Mindestzahl der Dresdner Bombenopfer nach oben korrigiert'']{{dead link|date=October 2014}} (“lowest number of Dresden raids casualties corrected upwards”) * Minimum 20,000 – Allied airforce [[bombing of Berlin]] in 363 separate raids that took place during the period 7 June 1940 until 25 March 1944 * Minimum 20,000 – German [[Luftwaffe]] [[bombing of London]] during the [[The Blitz|Blitz]]; 7 September 1940 to 10 May 1941{{cite web|url=http://www.virtual-london.com/information/featured-articles/the-blitz.html |title=The Blitz – A-London-Guide.com |publisher=Virtual-london.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402083008/http://www.virtual-london.com/information/featured-articles/the-blitz.html |archivedate=2011-04-02 |df= }} * Around 18,000 – Royal Air Force [[Bombing of Pforzheim in World War II|bombing of Pforzheim]] on 23 February 1945 === Post-World War II === {{expand section|date=October 2018}} * 40,000–150,000 – U.S. bombing campaign of [[Cambodia]] (categorized as [[Operation Menu]] and [[Operation Freedom Deal]]) from 18 March 1969 to 15 August 1973 * 1,400 – [[Operation Linebacker II]] 'Christmas bombing' ([[Vietnam]]), 1972 * 428 to 5,700 – [[NATO bombing of Yugoslavia]], 1999 ==Individual air raids== ===World War II=== * 90,000–146,000 – [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|Atomic bombing of Hiroshima]] by the USAAF, (Japan, 1945) * 80,000-100,000 – [[USAAF]] [[Great Tokyo Air Raid|bombing of Tokyo]] on March 10, 1945{{cite web|author=Thomson Reuters Foundation |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/T137774.htm |title=Humanitarian | Thomson Reuters Foundation News |website=Alertnet.org |date= |accessdate=2017-02-22}} * 50,000 – [[Battle of Hamburg (air)|Battle of Hamburg]] (Germany, July 1943), week-long ''Operation Gomorrah'' by RAF and USAAF * 39,000–80,000 – [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|Atomic bombing of Nagasaki]] by the USAAF, (Japan, 1945) * 17,000– [[Bombing of Pforzheim in World War II#Main raid|Bombing of Pforzheim]] by Allies (Germany, February 23, 1945)Luke Harding, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/oct/22/worlddispatch.germany "Germany's forgotten victims"], ''Guardian'' 22 October 2003 * 7,500–8,500 – Fighter-bomber attacks on {{SS|Cap Arcona|1927|6}} and {{SS|Thielbek|1940|6}}, (Germany, 1945) * 2,300–17,000 – [[Bombing of Belgrade in World War II|Operation Punishment: Bombing of Belgrade by Nazi Germany]] (Yugoslavia, 1941) * 2,000–5,000 – Bombing of [[Le Havre]] by Allied forces (France, 1944) * 1,500–4,000 – [[Operation Charnwood|Bombing of Caen]] by Allied forces (France, 1944) * 2,403 – [[Bombing of Pearl Harbor]] by [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] (United States, 1941) * 1,200 – [[Bombing of Belgrade in World War II|Allied bombing of Belgrade]] ([[Yugoslavia]], 1944) * 800–900 – [[Rotterdam Blitz|Bombing of Rotterdam]] by [[Nazi {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Luna 2''}} {{Cleanup reorganize|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = ''Luna 2'' (Rus. ''Moon 2''/''Луна 2'') | image = Luna 2 Soviet moon probe.jpg | image_caption = ''Luna 2''
| mission_type = Lunar impactor | operator = [[Soviet Union]] | Harvard_designation = 1959 Xi 1 | COSPAR_ID = 1959-014A | SATCAT = 114 | mission_duration = 1 day, 14 hours, 22 minutes and 42 seconds (launch date to impact date)
| spacecraft_type = | manufacturer = [[OKB-1]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|390.2|kg|lb}} | power =
| launch_date = {{start-date|September 12, 1959, 06:39:42|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Luna (rocket)|Luna]] 8K72 | launch_site = [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] [[Baikonur Cosmodrome Site 1|1/5]] | launch_contractor =
| orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = <!--transfer orbit--> | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = | apsis =
|interplanetary = {{Infobox spaceflight/IP |type = impactor |object = [[Moon|Lunar]] |arrival_date = {{end-date|September 13, 1959, 21:02:24}} UTC |location = {{Lunar coords and quad cat|29.1|N|0|W}} }} }} '''''Luna 2''''' (E-1A series) or '''Lunik 2''' was the second of the [[Soviet Union|Soviet Union's]] [[Luna programme]] spacecraft launched to the [[Moon]]. It was the first spacecraft [[Moon landing|to reach the surface of the Moon]], and the first man-made object to land on another celestial body.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planetary.org/explore/space-topics/space-missions/missions-to-the-moon.html|title=Missions to the Moon |publisher=''planetary.org''}}</ref> On September 13, 1959, it hit the Moon's surface east of [[Mare Imbrium]] near the craters Aristides, [[Archimedes (crater)|Archimedes]], and [[Autolycus (crater)|Autolycus]].<ref name="nasa1"> {{cite web | url = http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1959-014A | title = ''Luna 2'' | publisher = NASA - NSSDC}}</ref>
==Mission profile==
Launch was scheduled for September 9, but the Blok I core stage was shut down after it failed to reach full thrust at ignition. The booster was removed from the pad and replaced by a different vehicle, delaying the flight by three days. ''Luna 2'', like ''[[Luna 1]]'', took a [[direct ascent|direct path]] to the Moon, with a velocity high enough to result in a travel time of around 36 hours. ''Luna 2'' hit the Moon about {{convert|800|km|mi|sp=us}} from the centre of the visible disk on 1959 September 13 at 21:02:24 [[Universal Coordinated Time|UTC]].<ref name="zarya.info">{{cite web |url=http://www.zarya.info/Diaries/Luna/Luna02.php |title=USSR ''Luna 2'' |publisher=''zarya.info''}}</ref>
[[File:Moon map Luna 17 Luna 2 Apollo 15 Surveyor 6 Surveyor 4 Luna 7 Luna 8 Luna 11.png|thumbnail|right |''Luna 2'' site is near the right of the image, close to the [[Apollo 15]] landing site]]
''Luna 2'' was similar in design to ''[[Luna 1]]'', a spherical spacecraft with protruding antennas and [[instrumentation]]. The instrumentation was also similar to Luna 1, including [[scintillation counters]], [[geiger counter]]s, a [[magnetometer]], [[Cherenkov radiation|Cherenkov]] detectors, and [[micrometeorite]] detectors. There were no propulsion systems on ''Luna 2'' itself.<ref name="zarya.info"/>
Once ''Luna 2'' was split from its upper stage it started transmitting information back to Earth using three different transmitters. These transmitters provided precise information on its course, allowing scientists to calculate that ''Luna 2'' would hit its mark on the Moon around 00:05 on September 14 ([[Moscow Time]]).<ref name="Harvey, B. 2007">Harvey, B. (2007). Soviet and Russian lunar exploration. Berlin: Springer. Pg.- 31-33</ref> In order to be able to provide a visual from Earth on September 13, the spacecraft released a vapor cloud that would expand to {{convert|650|km|mi|sp=us|adj=on}} diameter that would be seen by observatories in [[Alma Ata]], [[Byurakan]], [[Abastumani]], [[Tbilisi]], and [[Stalinabad]].<ref name="Harvey, B. 2007"/> This vapor cloud also acted as an experiment to see how the sodium gas would act in a vacuum and zero gravity.<ref name="nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov">Luna 2- NASA.Gov. (n.d.). Retrieved from http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/masterCatalog.do?sc=1959-014A</ref>
The last stage of the rocket that carried ''Luna 2'' did not carry any type of tracking device so there was uncertainty as to where it landed, but it did hit the [[Moon]] surface about 30 minutes after ''Luna 2'' hit.<ref name="nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov"/>
==Impact== For a time, [[United States|Americans]] were starting to believe that they were making progress in the space race and that although the [[Soviet Union|Soviets]] might have had larger rockets, the [[United States]] had better guidance systems. This myth was busted after the Soviets were able to crash ''Luna 2'' onto the Moon.<ref name="Cox, D. W. 1962 pg. 47, 118">Cox, D. W. (1962). The space race; from Sputnik to Apollo, and beyond. Philadelphia: Chilton Books. pg. 47, 118</ref> At that time the closest Americans had come to the Moon was about {{convert|37000|mi|km}} with [[Pioneer 4]].<ref>The Soviet Union is first to the Moon. (2009). History Today, 59(9), 10.</ref> Khrushchev, on his only visit to the U.S., gave president Eisenhower a replica of the Soviet pennants that ''Luna 2'' had just placed onto the lunar surface.<ref>[[Nicholas Daniloff|Daniloff, N.]] (1972). The Kremlin and the cosmos. New York: Knopf. Pg.- 105</ref> ''Luna 2'' and its predecessors all came to be used throughout the USSR and around the world as pro-communist propaganda. Donald W. Cox explains, in his book ''The Space Race'', “Although the [[Sputnik 1|Sputniks]] and [[Luna programme|Luniks]] did not themselves provide better cars, refrigerators, color TV sets, and homes for the peasants and laborers of the Soviet Union and her satellite states, they did evoke added inspiration for the earthbound followers of the [[Communism|communist]] way of life helping to take their minds off shortages of consumer goods. The people were spurred on to work just a little harder for the glorious motherland and to outstrip the west in the less dramatic and more basic things of life, like coal and steel production.”<ref name="Cox, D. W. 1962 pg. 47, 118"/> Although ''Luna 2'' was a success for the Soviets, it also helped the U.S. by starting a trend of crash landing. It would eventually lead to the U.S.-made [[Ranger program|Rangers]] which would go on to also crash land on the Moon in exactly the same way. Crash landing proved useful even after soft landing was mastered. [[NASA]] used crash landings to test whether Moon craters contained ice by crashing space probes into craters and testing the debris that got thrown out.<ref>Philips, T. (n.d.). Crash Landing on the Moon - NASA Science. Retrieved April 20, 2016, from https://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2006/28jul_crashlanding/</ref>
==Experiments== ''Luna 2'' carried 5 different instruments to conduct various tests while it was on its way to [[the Moon]]. The scintillation counters would be used to measure any ionizing radiation; the [[Cherenkov radiation]] detectors would be measuring for electromagnetic radiation caused by charged particles. “The Geiger Counter carried on ''Luna 2'' had the primary scientific objective of determining the electron spectrum of the outer radiation belt. The instrument consisted of three STS-5 gas-discharge counters mounted on the outside of the hermetically sealed container, and would be powered by a 360 V battery”.<ref>Geiger Counter- NASA.Gov. (n.d.). Retrieved from http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experimentDisplay.do?id=1959-014A-02</ref> The last instrument on Luna 2 was, “a three component fluxgate magnetometer similar to that used on Luna 1 but with the dynamic range reduced by a factor of 4 to -750 to +750 gammas so that the quantization uncertainty was -12 to +12 gammas.”<ref name="ReferenceA">Triaxial Fluxgate Magnetometer- NASA.Gov. (n.d.). Retrieved from http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experimentDisplay.do?id=1959-014A-01</ref> Together the devices were searching for lunar magnetic and radiation fields similar to the [[Van Allen radiation belt]] around Earth, sending information about once every minute<ref name="ReferenceA"/> until its last transmission which came about 55 km away from the lunar surface.<ref name="ReferenceB">Harvey, B. (2007). Soviet and Russian lunar exploration. Berlin: Springer. Pg.- 31-33,</ref> Although it did prove previous measurements of the Van Allen radiation belts that were taken from Luna 1 around the Earth, it was not able to detect any type of radiation belts around the Moon. Because of claims that information received from Luna 1 was fake, as soon as the scientists of ''Luna 2'' started receiving transmissions they sent out the intended time of impact, and the transmission and trajectory details.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Even though Soviet scientists gave all this information, the Americans were still skeptical until [[Bernard Lovell]] was able to prove that the radio signal was coming from ''Luna 2'' by showing the Doppler shift from its transmissions. After this no one seemed to question the veracity of the Soviets.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
==Van Allen radiation belt== ''Luna 2'' showed time variations in the [[electric flux|electron flux]] and [[energy spectrum]] in the [[Van Allen radiation belt]].
==USSR pennants== [[File:Kansas Cosmosphere Luna 2 Pennant 2013.JPG|thumb|The copy of the Soviet pennant sent on the ''Luna 2'' probe to the Moon, at the Kansas Cosmosphere]]
<!--info from Russian sources starts--> The spacecraft also carried Soviet [[Pennant (commissioning)|pennant]]s. Two of them, located in the spacecraft, were sphere-shaped, with the surface covered by identical [[pentagon]]al elements. In the center was an explosive charge designed to shatter the sphere, sending the pentagonal shields in all directions. This was a low-tech method that would blow back a few elements in the direction opposite of its velocity vector to greatly reduce the energy upon reaching the surface (in the way that [[lander (spacecraft)|landers]] are designed to reduce velocity) which would improve the chance that some part of the sphere might survive the impact. Each pentagonal element was made of [[stainless steel]] and had the [[USSR Coat of Arms]] and the [[Cyrillic]] letters ''СССР'' ("USSR") engraved on one side, and the words ''СССР январь 1959'' ("USSR January 1959") on the other side. They most likely vaporized on impact, however.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mentallandscape.com/V_Pennants.htm|title=Soviet Spacecraft Pennants|accessdate=8 December 2014}}</ref> The third pennant was located in the last stage of the ''Luna 2'' rocket, which collided with the Moon's surface 30 minutes after the spacecraft did. It was a capsule filled with liquid, with [[aluminium]] strips placed into it. On each of these strips the USSR Coat of Arms, the words ''1959 январь'' ("1959 January"), and the words ''СОЮЗ СОВЕТСКИХ СОЦИАЛИСТИЧЕСКИХ РЕСПУБЛИК'' (English: "Union of Soviet Socialist Republics") were engraved.
On September 15, 1959, the premier of the Soviet Union, [[Nikita Khrushchev]], presented the American president [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] with a copy of the spherical pennant as a gift. That sphere is kept at the [[Eisenhower Presidential Center|Eisenhower Presidential Library and Museum]] in [[Abilene, Kansas]]. The only other known copy of the spherical pennant is located at the [[Kansas Cosmosphere and Space Center|Kansas Cosmosphere]] in [[Hutchinson, Kansas]]. <!--info from Russian sources ends-->
==See also== {{Portal|Moon|Spaceflight}} *[[Soviet space program]] *[[Sinus Lunicus]] *[[List of artificial objects on the Moon]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{one source|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox political party | colorcode = {{Moderate Party (Italy)/meta/color}} | name = Moderate Party | native_name = Partito Moderato | logo = | leader = [[Vincenzo Gioberti]]
[[Cesare Balbo]] | foundation = {{Start date|1848}} | dissolution = {{End date|1861}} | headquarters = [[Turin]], [[Kingdom of Sardinia|Piedmont-Sardinia]] | ideology = [[Big tent|Catch-all]]
[[Confederalism]]{{cite book|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=c6bNxs_7miwC|title=I moderati: neoguelfi e liberal-radicali|work=Tutta storia|editor=DeAgostini|date=2011|page=311}}
[[Romantic nationalism]]{{cite book|last=Formichi|first=Gianluca|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=rrkM6vPOBDAC|title=Il Risorgimento: 1799-1861|editor=Giunti|date=2003|page=49}}{{cite book|last=Nascimbene Pasio|first=Clelia|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=zUk-AAAAIAAJ|title=Patriottismo romantico e patriottismo classico nei prodromi del risorgimento italiano|editor=Zanichelli|date=1931|page=104}}
'''Factions''':
[[House of Savoy|Savoyard]]{{nbsp}}[[monarchism]]{{nbsp}}
[[Pope|Papal]] [[monarchism]]{{cite book |last=Schiattone |first=Mario |url= https://books.google.it/books?id=9TykdLn5ozEC |title= Alle origini del federalismo italiano |editor= Dedalo |date=1996 |page=76}}{{cite book |last=Fusilli |first=Raffaele |url= https://books.google.it/books?id=d_0NAQAAIAAJ |title= Liberali, socialcomunisti e cattolici in lotta guelfa e ghibellina durante il fascismo, la monarchia e la repubblica: Saggio storico politico |date= 1969}}
[[Republicanism]] (minority) | country = Italy }} The '''Moderate Party''' ({{lang-it|Partito Moderato}}), collectively called '''Moderates''' ({{lang-it|Moderati}}), was an Italian pre-Unification political rally, active during the [[Risorgimento]] (1815–1861). The Moderates were never a formal party, but only a movement of liberal-minded reformist patriots, usually secular, from politics, military, literature and philosophy. ==History== Since the [[Congress of Vienna]], inside the [[Italian Peninsula]] was diffused a [[reformist]] and [[Romanticism|Romantic]] moment, inspired from [[Jacobin (politics)|Jacobonism]] and [[Bonapartism]] and explosed in the [[revolutions of 1820]] against the [[reactionary]] [[Congress System]]. Many patriots, soldiers and intellectuals who took part to the revolutions were definited "moderates".{{clarify|date=February 2018}} The Moderates, with time, demarcated themselves from radical and republican organizations like [[Giuseppe Mazzini]]'s [[Young Italy (historical)|Young Italy]], ''[[Carboneria]]'' and others. The moderates and radicals disputed mainly for the methods to unified Italy: the Moderates supported secret pacts and strategic alliances between the patriotic movement and the other European powers, whereas the Mazzini's supporters called a popular revolution to establish a democratic Republic. After the failure of the [[Revolutions of 1848 in the Italian states|Italian Revolutions of 1848]], attempted by Mazzinians and republicans, the republican ideas declined for the Moderates' agenda. During this time, several politicians of other Italian states are members of the group: in the [[Kingdom of Sardinia]], the leaders were [[Massimo d'Azeglio]] and [[Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour]], representing the parliamentary [[Historical Right|Right]], and [[Urbano Rattazzi]], representing the [[Historical Left|Left]]; in the [[Papal States]] the reform movement was headed by [[Terenzio, Count Mamiani della Rovere|Terenzio della Rovere]] and [[Pellegrino Rossi]], the last murdered by a republican plot in 1848; in the [[Kingdom of the Two Sicilies]] prominent moderates were brothers [[Bertrando Spaventa|Bertrando]] and [[Silvio Spaventa]]. When the [[Kingdom of Italy]] was founded in 1861, the moderates merged in the Historical Right and Left, the two Piedmontese parliamentary group that monopolized the politics of the new Italian state for almost half-century. ==Tendencies and members== Differently by democrats and radical republicans, the Moderates were only circles of intellectuals, aristocrats, soldiers and businessmen with patriotic tendencies. However, the Moderate Party wasn't cohesive, because its members were of different political ideologies, from continental [[liberalism]] to soft [[conservatism]]. Initially, the party wasn't too nationalist, preferring a [[federation]] or coalition between the several Italian states, and support both [[reformist]] and [[law and order (politics)|law and order]] policies, different by the republicans like Mazzini. When the possibility of an unified Italian state became real, a new question of division was the form that the new Italian State would have. Someone, like [[Vincenzo Gioberti]], supported a [[confederation]] of states, led by the [[Pope]].{{cite web|url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/partito-moderato/|title=Partito Moderato|publisher=Encilopedia Treccani}} other simply claimed for a [[centralized]] state headed by a [[monarch]], without differences if a [[House of Savoy|Savoy]] or other. There were three main tendencies inside the movement:
'''[[Neo-Guelphism|Neo-Guelphs]]''': * [[Vincenzo Gioberti]] * [[Carlo Troya]] * [[Alessandro Manzoni]]{{cite book|URL=https://books.google.it/books?id=KAvK8z-hf7gC&pg=PA93&lpg=PA93&dq=manzoni+neo+guelfo&source=bl&ots=gcVVAQrwRP&sig=TM84d0dsaH3Ec3dnerIQY73FLEM&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjkjvvFoZHWAhVJwBQKHQKeC-cQ6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=manzoni%20neo%20guelfo&f=false|title=The Count of Carmagnola & Adelchis|author=[[Alessandro Manzoni]]|publisher=[[Johns Hopkins University Press|JHU Press]]|date=August 3, 2004|page=93}}{{cite news|language=Italian|title=L' idealismo neo-guelfo e il teatro nazionale in Alessandro Manzoni|author=Stelio Cro|magazine=Tetaro Contemporaneo|date=February–May 1988}} * [[Terenzio, Count Mamiani della Rovere|Terenzio della Rovere]] * [[Pellegrino Rossi]] * [[Antonio Rosmini-Serbati]] * [[Gino Capponi]] * [[Carlo Matteucci]] * [[Luigi Tosti]]
'''Neutral''': * [[Gabrio Casati]] * [[Cesare Alfieri di Sostegno]] * [[Massimo d'Azeglio]] * [[Luigi Settembrini]] * [[Carlo Zucchi (general)|Carlo Zucchi]] * [[Ruggero Settimo]] * [[Carlo Filangieri]]
'''Neo-Ghibellines''':{{cite news|url=https://www.skuola.net/storia-contemporanea/neoghibellini-moderati.html|title=Neoghibellini e moderati|website=Skuola.net|access-date=18 June 2018}}{{cite book|last=Badaloni|first=Nicola|title=Il pensiero politico di Francesco Domenico Guerrazzi|editor=Quaderni della Labronica|date=1974|page=67}} * [[Cesare Balbo]] (switched side){{cite book|last=Viglione|first=Massimo|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=PQ0rCZzvOB4C|title=Libera chiesa in libero stato?: il Risorgimento e i cattolici: uno scontro epocale|editor=Città Nuova|date=2005|pages=44-45}} * [[Carlo Cattaneo]] (left for [[Action Party (Italy, 1848)|Action Party]]) * [[Annibale Santorre di Rossi de Pomarolo, Count of Santarosa|Santorre de Rossi, Count of Santarosa]] * [[Francesco Domenico Guerrazzi]]{{cite book|last1=Gnoli|first1=Antonio|last2=Sasso|first2=Gennaro|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=UmqgDQAAQBAJ|title=I corrotti e gli inetti: Conversazioni su Machiavelli|editor=Giunti|date=2013}}{{cite book|last=Firpo|first=Luigi|url=https://books.google.it/books?hl=it&id=FtM6AAAAIAAJ|title=Storia delle idee politiche economiche e sociali|volume=3|editor=Unione Tipografico-Editrice Torinese|date=1972|page=291}} * [[Giovanni Battista Niccolini]] * [[Gabriele Rossetti]] * [[Florestano Pepe]] * [[Guglielmo Pepe]]
{{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==See also== * [[Liberalism and radicalism in Italy]] {{19th century Italian political groups}} [[Category:Liberal parties in Italy]] [[Category:Italian unification]] [[Category:Kingdom of Sardinia]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Italy]] [[Category:1848 establishments in Italy]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1848]] [[Category:1861 disestablishments in Italy]] [[Category:Defunct liberal political parties]]
